node.title: Healthcare workers under pressure due to COVID were offered bonuses, but many are still waiting
node.alt: A nurse pulls up a syringe of COVID-19 vaccine.
node.description: Multiple health services say payments of up to $300 per week for workers under pressure in the face of Victoria's Delta outbreak are still being sorted out almost two months after being announced.
node.content:
["Several Victorian hospitals are lagging behind paying bonuses to frontline workers who were promised extra money as COVID cases soared this year.", "The Hospital Surge Support Payments, announced by the state government on October 12 as part of a $255 million package, were seen as a small reward for workers who completed entire shifts in full PPE, often in hospitals with staff shortages.", "\"The challenges they are dealing with on all our behalf require this unprecedented response,\" Health Minister Martin Foley said at the time.", "Since then, some hospital networks say issuing the bonuses has been an administrative nightmare.", "In some cases, workers have received little or none of the allowances of up to $300 per week, but have been promised the money will eventually come.", "Last week, the ABC reported some eligible Eastern Health staff were owed about $2,000.", "This week, the Royal Women's Hospital said it was \"working through back pay entitlements\", but was unable to say how many members of its workforce had been impacted.", "\"This is a time-consuming and in some cases a manual process, and it is important our calculations and determination of eligibility are correct,\" a spokesperson said.", "Austin Health said it was finalising the remaining back pay owing to staff. Mercy Health, which runs the hospital in Werribee, is also understood to be behind in payments.", "Nurses, doctors and midwives in public hospitals were promised an extra $60 shift allowance for four months if they worked on COVID wards or emergency departments.", "Some workers in other units were to receive between $15 and $30 per shift, depending on their role.", "", "
Some workers at Albury Wodonga Health are owed back pay.(Supplied: Albury Wodonga Health)
", "Paul Greenhalch, the chief executive of the South Gippsland Hospital, said he wholeheartedly supported the allowances for workers, but said his health service was given no notice before the state government announced the bonuses on October 12.", "\"We had to do a lot of work in the back end of the payroll system,\" he said.", "Eligible workers at Central Gippsland Health, which runs the Sale Hospital, are owed about two months of bonus payments. According to an all-staff email, some payments will be made after December 12 and \"then hopefully catch up fully in the following pay run\".", "About 150 staff from East Grampians Health Service would next week receive backdated bonuses from October 11, chief executive Peter Armstrong said.", "Albury Wodonga Health said about 75 of its workers would this week receive back pay that was owing.", "The nurses union has previously said it \"cannot fathom\" why it had taken so long for some workers to be paid and urged health services to \"act with urgency\".", "The ABC contacted dozens of health services for this story. Several said they were up-to-date with the bonus payments.", "Others gave opaque answers, without saying if their workers were owed money. Some did not respond to questions.", "A spokesperson said the Victorian Government was\u00a0aware of payment processing issues at some health services and they\u00a0would\u00a0be rectified within in the next few days.", "", "
